resources.string:
APRAD (Autonomous Portable low frequency Receiver And Display) provides a means of measuring and analyzing electromagnetic waves in the environment. 
It provides two main functionalities: 

The Spectrum Analyzer provides real-time representations of input signals. The Spectrum Analyzer displays the frequencies on the horizontal (x) axis and the amplitude of those frequencies on the vertical (y) axis. The signal is generated with Fourier analysis of the input electrical signal. With the APRAD antenna attached, the Analyzer will display the electromagnetic signal of the surrounding electromagnetic radiation within the limits of the device. The Analyzer can also be take advantage of the microphone input of the mobile device. 

The Spectrogram displays the frequency and amplitude data as a function of time, with the amplitude represented by color. The frequency data is shown on the vertical (y) axis while the horizontal (x) axis represents time in seconds. The amplitude graph on the right edge of the Spectrogram screen indicates frequencies with small amplitude with a dark blue color. The color changes as amplitude increases to display lighter blue, green, yellow and red for the most intense frequency signals.
 The Start/Stop Recording button in the upper left corner of the Spectrogram screen begins the signal capture process. When the Spectrogram is first selected from the menu, it begins recording data immediately. In order to stop recording, simply press the Stop Recording button at the top left corner of the screen. A prompt to save the recorded data will appear. Select either to Save the data or to Cancel the save. Once the recording of Spectrogram data is stopped, the actual amount of time recorded (in seconds) will be shown in the upper right corner of the screen. The Spectrogram allows the user to save the captured data (up to a maximum of 60 seconds). Multiple recordings may be taken by pressing the Start Recording button in the upper left corner of the screen. 

The Education section provides many educational features. 
It can simulate waves, open previously captured and saved spectrogram wave data, and allows the user to view raw captured data. 
The Synthesize Wave Data section prompts the user to enter up to three frequency and time pairs, and once the user hits the <Go> button, the wave(s) will be graphed as they would theorectically interact with each other. 
The Use Saved Wave Data section allows the user to pull up previously captured and saved wave data, and will display the saved data in a spectrogram. 
The View Raw Signal section allows the user to see the ambient waves data in the time domain. This is a different view than either the Spectrum Analyzer or the Spectrogram.
